cost_objection.objection: Your fees are too expensive / I can't afford this right now
cost_objection.underlying_fear: What if I pay this and don't get results? What if I waste money I need for other things?
cost_objection.authentic_response: I understand the investment feels significant. Let's look at the actual numbers: you mentioned [SPECIFIC_PROBLEM] is costing you approximately [AMOUNT] per month. Our work together will [SPECIFIC_OUTCOME] within [TIMEFRAME], which means you'll recover the investment in [PAYBACK_PERIOD]. The real question is whether you can afford to keep losing [AMOUNT] monthly while trying to figure this out alone. What if we structured this as [PAYMENT_TERMS] to align with your cash flow?
cost_objection.reframe: From expense to investment with measurable ROI and manageable cash flow

timing_objection.objection: Now isn't the right time / Let me think about it
timing_objection.underlying_fear: What if I commit and can't follow through? What if something more urgent comes up?
timing_objection.authentic_response: I appreciate wanting to time this right. In my experience, there's never a 'perfect' time—there's always something else competing for attention. The question is: what changes between now and [FUTURE_DATE] that makes this easier? Usually nothing, which means you're just extending the problem. That said, if there's a genuine constraint like [SPECIFIC_REASON], let's discuss timing that works. But if it's about waiting for things to calm down, they won't—that's exactly why you need this.
timing_objection.reframe: From 'bad timing' to 'timing will never be perfect, and delay has costs'

diy_objection.objection: I think I can figure this out myself / I'll try some things first
diy_objection.underlying_fear: Maybe I don't really need help. Maybe I'm not trying hard enough on my own.
diy_objection.authentic_response: You absolutely could figure this out yourself—you're clearly capable, that's how you built what you have. The question is timeline and opportunity cost. How long have you been working on [SPECIFIC_PROBLEM]? What has that cost you in lost revenue, stress, and missed opportunities? I help you compress 18-24 months of trial-and-error into 90-120 days of focused execution. You're not paying me because you can't do it—you're paying me because you can't afford the time it would take to do it alone. What's your time worth?
diy_objection.reframe: From 'need help' to 'accelerate results and avoid expensive mistakes'

trust_objection.objection: How do I know this will work for my specific situation?
trust_objection.underlying_fear: What if my business is too different? What if they don't really understand my industry?
trust_objection.authentic_response: That's the right question to ask. Here's what I know about [THEIR_INDUSTRY/SITUATION]: [SPECIFIC_INSIGHTS]. I've worked with [NUMBER] companies facing [SIMILAR_CHALLENGE], and while every business has unique aspects, the core dynamics of [PROBLEM_AREA] are consistent. What I can't guarantee is specific outcomes—too many variables. What I can guarantee is that we'll use proven methodologies, I'll bring [SPECIFIC_EXPERTISE], and if after [TIMEFRAME] you don't see [MEASURABLE_PROGRESS], we'll [SPECIFIC_REMEDY]. Would it help to speak with [REFERENCE_CLIENT] who had similar concerns?
trust_objection.reframe: From 'prove it will work' to 'here's how we'll know it's working and what we'll do if it's not'

authority_objection.objection: I need to discuss this with my partner/board/team first

Let me provide you with [ROI_ANALYSIS/CASE_STUDY/SCOPE_DOCUMENT] that addresses the business case clearly. Would it be helpful if I joined that conversation to answer their questions directly? pricing_psychology.anchor_high: Lead with premium package ($15K-50K) to make mid-tier ($5K-15K) feel reasonable. Show the high-end option first in all presentations.

pricing_psychology.payment_terms: Offer 'invest today' discount vs. payment plans. $10K paid upfront vs. $12K over 6 months - creates urgency and improves cash flow.
pricing_psychology.package_naming: Avoid 'Basic/Standard/Premium' - use aspirational names: 'Foundation Builder', 'Growth Accelerator', 'Market Dominator'.
pricing_psychology.decoy_pricing: Include a strategically overpriced option to make target package look like best value. $25K option makes $12K option the 'smart choice'.
pricing_psychology.price_framing: Present as monthly investment not total cost - '$2,500/month for 6 months' feels smaller than '$15,000 engagement'.

twitter_content_templates.hook_tweet: I've helped 50+ companies scale to 8-figures. Here's the exact framework we use (most consultants won't share this):
thread_structure: I've helped 50+ companies scale to 8-figures. Here's the exact framework we use (most consultants won't share this):
The problem: 90% of businesses don't have a growth bottleneck. They have a clarity bottleneck.
Step 1: The Revenue Audit - Map every dollar coming in and identify which 20% of activities drive 80% of results
Step 2: The Constraint Analysis - Find the ONE thing holding you back (hint: it's usually not what you think)
Step 3: The 90-Day Sprint - Focus exclusively on removing that constraint. Nothing else matters.
Step 4: Measure, iterate, repeat. Most companies quit here. Winners double down.
Real example: Client was stuck at $2M/year. Found their constraint (sales process). Fixed it. Hit $5M in 18 months.
The framework is simple. Execution is hard. That's where most fail.
Want the full playbook? Drop a comment and I'll send you the worksheet we use with clients.

What they actually needed: Someone to tell the CEO his brother-in-law was destroying the company

thread_structure: Client went from $800K to $4.2M in 14 months. Here's the counterintuitive strategy we used:
Background: B2B SaaS, 8 employees, decent product, terrible positioning
Everyone told them to: Build more features, hire salespeople, run ads
We did the opposite: Fired 2 clients, niched down to one vertical, raised prices 3x
Month 1-3: Revenue actually DROPPED. Team panicked. CEO questioned everything.
Month 4: First deal at new price point. $85K annual contract. Game changed.
Month 6-12: Word spread in the niche. Referrals exploded. Hired 4 people.
Month 14: Hit $4.2M run rate. Same product. Smaller target market. Higher prices.
The lesson: Addition by subtraction. Most companies are trying to serve everyone and winning with no one.
Specificity > Scale. Every. Single. Time.

thread_structure: I charged a client $75K for advice that nearly bankrupted them. Here's what I got catastrophically wrong:
Context: Manufacturing company, 30 employees, $8M revenue, healthy margins
My recommendation: Automate production, reduce headcount, increase efficiency
Textbook consulting advice. I was proud of the deck.
What happened: They automated. Laid off 12 people. Efficiency went up 40%.
Then: Quality dropped. Customer complaints spiked. Lost 3 major accounts in 60 days.
The employees they fired? They were the quality control. The 'inefficiency' was actually craftsmanship.
Revenue dropped $2M in 6 months. I had optimized them into irrelevance.
The lesson: Not everything that can be measured matters. Not everything that matters can be measured.
I refunded the fee. Helped them rebuild. Learned to respect what I don't understand.
10 years later, I still think about this when someone asks me to 'increase efficiency.'

twitter_content_templates.hook_tweet: Steal this: The 15-minute exercise that's generated $12M+ in new revenue for my clients (requires zero budget):
thread_structure: Steal this: The 15-minute exercise that's generated $12M+ in new revenue for my clients (requires zero budget):
It's called the 'Revenue Leak Audit' and it's stupidly simple:
Step 1: List every place you interact with customers (website, email, calls, invoices, etc)
Step 2: For each touchpoint, ask: 'Where do people drop off or say no?'
Step 3: Pick the ONE leak losing you the most money
Step 4: Fix that one thing this week. Ignore everything else.
Example: Client found 40% of people abandoned their checkout at the payment page. Fixed the confusing form. +$800K/year.
Example 2: Client discovered 60% of prospects said 'maybe later' after price discussion. Changed pricing structure. +$1.2M/year.
You don't need a consultant for this. You need 15 minutes and brutal honesty.
Do this exercise. Reply with what you found. I'll tell you which leak to fix first.
